greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into three distinct primes.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller and Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from Reinhard Zumkeller)
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n == 0, {1, 0, 0, 0}, If[i<1, {0, 0, 0, 0}, Plus @@ PadRight[{b[n, i-1], Join[{0}, If[Prime[i]>n, {0, 0, 0}, Take[b[n-Prime[i], i-1], 3]]]}]]]; a[n_] := b[n, PrimePi[n]][[4]]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 30 2014, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)

dp3Q[{a_,b_,c_}]:=Length[Union[{a,b,c}]]==3&&AllTrue[{a,b,c},PrimeQ]; Table[ Count[IntegerPartitions[n,{3}],_?dp3Q],{n,100}] (* The program uses the AllTrue function from Mathematica version 10 *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jan 30 2019 *)
xref: Column k=3 of A219180. - _Alois P. Heinz_, Nov 13 2012
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 30 2006
